title: Ben 10 Runner - Made using Pygame
contentHTML: A Ben 10–themed endless runner — my first ever finished game.
Ben 10 Runner was my introduction to both Python and Pygame — a fully playable endless runner game, and the first time I ever felt like I’d “finished” something real.
It started as a simple YouTube tutorial, but quickly spiraled into something of my own.
I added parallax backgrounds, enemy animations, and even experimented with a power-up system where Ben could transform into aliens — though I eventually removed it due to bugs and balance issues.
(Some of the old code still lingers in the files as proof of that brief experiment.)

I didn’t release this game publicly — most of the assets came from random sources and I didn’t track licenses at the time. But it remains my most cherished project, because it’s what made me realize how fun and addictive game development can be.
• † First solo game built entirely in Python

title: RayCaster - A simple Raycasting engine with pygame
contentHTML: A weekend rabbit hole into how DOOM faked 3D in 1993.
This was a spontaneous project, born after watching a YouTube video about the original DOOM. I asked myself,
“How did they make 3D games without real 3D engines?” The answer was raycasting — a clever illusion built with trigonometry.
I followed tutorials from creators like monkey see monkey do and FinFet, breaking down the math behind early 90s engines.
It blew my mind how simple formulas could trick the eye into seeing depth.
It’s not a real 3D engine — you can’t look up or down — but it felt like uncovering game dev archaeology.
Bonus trivia: John Carmack and Romero didn’t use version control while building DOOM. Insane.
• † Built solo in a weekend for fun

title: crossHair - A minigame made in pygame
contentHTML: It’s not really a game — just something fun to click around with.
crossHair is a simple mouse-based minigame I made while learning Pygame.
There’s no real goal — just click targets with a crosshair, watch them disappear, and enjoy the simplicity.
It’s tiny, rough, and not worth its own repo — but I’m still fond of it.
It reminds me of the small wins that kept me going during the learning curve.
• † Made during early Pygame learning phase
